bibl.title: Letter from Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon to Philip Showalter Hench, September 11, 1941

div1.p: Rodriguez Leon compliments Hench on his yellow fever history work, and wishes she had more time to devote to the research herself. She has been unable to find the information Hench seeks in her father's papers and fears that the rest of the papers will not be helpful either.

div1.head: Letter from Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon to Philip Showalter Hench, September 11, 1941
div1.opener:
15 No 311 - Vedado,
Habana, Cuba,
Sept. 11/41.
Dr. Philip S. Hench,
Rochester, Minnesota.
Dear Dr Hench:
div1.p:
Again I have allowed my
correspondence to lay, and I
find I owe you more than one letter.
Sorry, wish I could promise not
to repeat. But you must know
me by now, I am afraid.

In the first place allow
me to congratulate you for your
address at the unveiling of Wyeth's
paintings. You are certainly build-
ing up a reputation for oratory and
I can foretell you will be finding
it harder and harder not to comply
with ever greater demands upon
your energy. I must say I am
very glad that the Yellow Fever pro-
blem has fallen into such good hands.
Ac
Ag to Am
II
You seem to have the flare of the historian
coupled with the training of a good doc-
tor for clear thinking and with such
weapons I am sure you will finally
unearth the truth at last. For myself
I consider it a duty to leave that accom-
plished for future investigators, and
if other urgent demands did not cons-
tantly interfere with my good intentions.
Was your speech finally published?
I have been looking through several
issues of “Hygeia” but have not come
accross it.

Your last letter and Dr Alber-
tini's quoted analysis of the picture
of cuban doctors. It is very interesting
and he is probably right. I know
or have known most of the men, but
of course I recall them as much
older and considerably changed.

As to the Gorgas Speech I
am inclined to think also, that there
must be some mistake in the num-
bering of the pages. I have not been
able to sense any lapse in the con-
III
text. The numbering on the right corners
is mine, evidently made before sending
to you and, perhaps because I might
have noticed some discrepancy in my
father's numbers. I really don't remem-
ber exactly, but it seems unnecessary
to worry.

I am sorry to say I have not
done much to get at the odd statement
of Carroll's about my Father's trip
at the time Lazear's illness. I am posi-
tive it is untrue and hope to finally
be able to establish the fact. So far
I have gone through several packs
of old letters and papers to no avail.

I'll have dissapointing news
to give you when I say that I
found nothing, either, at the farm.
I went through the boxes hurriedly
but thoroughly this summer: noth-
ing in them but reprints and clip-
pings (duplicates) of the ones here. One
trunk of letters and family papers
I brought back with me, but I
IV
doubt that it may contain anything very-
enlightening. Only, perhaps, the facts
about the trip (Caroll's assertion).

Unfortunately the latter part of my
vacation was cut short by some new
plans and activities. There seems, an opening
may occur in the near future at the
University. I am intensely busy now
on some extra post-graduate work
in order to obtain my long neglected
Ph.D. as soon as possibly (I am already
Dr. in Education) The work would
ordinarily take 2 - 3 years; I am try-
ing to do it in 1 - 1 1/2, though rather
doubtful if I can, on account of
my teaching at Ruston, which I shall
have to keep up. I am telling you
all this so you will be patient with
me if I don't seem very active in
helping you with what really lies so
much nearer my own heart. Possibly,
if easier times are ahead, it shall be
possible some day to devote most of my
time to it.

Please give my regards to Mrs.
Hench. My husband joins me.

Hoping you will again come
down to Cuba this year, believe me,
